P.title: Will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A hemispherectomy is
a very rare neurosurgical procedure in which a cerebral hemisphere (half of the brain) is removed, disconnected, or disabled. This procedure is used to treat a variety of seizure disorders where the source of the epilepsy is localized to a broad area of a single hemisphere of the brain, notably Rasmussen's encephalitis. [...]
Because of the dramatic alteration of brain composition and the inherent risk that hemispherectomies pose, there are criteria that must be met in order for a person to qualify for the procedure. Criteria include no successful control of seizures throughout a variety of drug trials, and a reasonable to high chance of procedural success.
One such predictor of success is often the age of the patient. This procedure is almost exclusively performed in children because their brains generally display more neuroplasticity, allowing neurons from the remaining hemisphere to take over the tasks from the lost hemisphere. [...]
The success of the procedure is not, however, limited to children. A study in 2007 indicated the long-term efficacy of anatomic hemispherectomy in carefully selected adults, with seizure control sustainable over multiple decades. A case study published in 2015 of 2 adults aged 48 and 38 demonstrated the success of functional hemispherectomy in treating status epilepticus (SE), an epileptic condition in which seizures are prolonged or occur closely together. In 2012, a case study following 30 individuals having undergone some form of hemispherectomy in adulthood found that 81% of individuals were seizure free post-procedure. Furthermore, almost all participating patients reported improved quality of life. The conclusion: “adult patients do not have to expect more problems with new deficits, appear to cope quite well, and most profit from surgery in several quality of life domains.”
While hemispherectomies are generally reserved as a treatment for extreme cases of seizure disorders, they could conceivably aid in life extension as well. In particular, a patient could voluntarily receive a hemispherectomy in order to cryopreserve and put their brain in long-term storage while they are still living, thereby increasing the probability that their personality and identity are stored in some sort of medium, persisting into the future.
So far as I can tell, a hemispherectomy performed for the purpose of life extension is purely hypothetical. Furthermore, there are few to no current online resources about this possibility (besides this one).
This question asks, will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
Here the resolution is determined by the conjunction of three actions, performed by an individual human:
They received a hemispherectomy voluntarily.
Half of their brain was placed in long-term cryopreservation while they were still legally alive.
They reported in some credible source (such as through a media outlet, or via a forum with strong evidence of credibility) that the procedure was done primarily for the purpose of extending their life.

para_P.title: Will an individual claim to have undergone a hemispherectomy for life extension purposes before the year 2100?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A hemispherectomy is a highly uncommon neurosurgical operation where one cerebral hemisphere (half of the brain) is removed, disconnected, or disabled. This surgery is typically used to address various seizure disorders where the epilepsy source is localized to a broad area within one hemisphere of the brain, notably Rasmussen's encephalitis. [...]
Due to the significant alteration of brain structure and the inherent risks associated with hemispherectomies, specific criteria must be met for a person to qualify for the procedure. These criteria include unsuccessful seizure control through various drug trials and a reasonable to high chance of procedural success.
One predictor of success is often the patient's age. This surgery is almost exclusively performed on children because their brains generally exhibit more neuroplasticity, allowing neurons from the remaining hemisphere to take over the functions of the lost hemisphere. [...]
However, the procedure's success is not limited to children. A 2007 study indicated the long-term efficacy of anatomic hemispherectomy in carefully selected adults, with seizure control sustainable over multiple decades. A 2015 case study of two adults aged 48 and 38 demonstrated the success of functional hemispherectomy in treating status epilepticus (SE), a condition where seizures are prolonged or occur in quick succession. In 2012, a case study of 30 adults who underwent some form of hemispherectomy found that 81% were seizure-free post-procedure. Additionally, almost all participants reported an improved quality of life. The conclusion: “adult patients do not have to expect more problems with new deficits, appear to cope quite well, and most benefit from surgery in several quality of life domains.”
While hemispherectomies are generally reserved for extreme seizure disorder cases, they could theoretically assist in life extension. Specifically, a patient could voluntarily undergo a hemispherectomy to cryopreserve and store their brain long-term while still alive, thereby increasing the likelihood that their personality and identity are preserved in some medium, continuing into the future.
As far as I can tell, a hemispherectomy performed for life extension purposes is purely theoretical. Moreover, there are few to no current online resources discussing this possibility (besides this one).
This question asks, will an individual claim to have undergone a hemispherectomy for life extension purposes before the year 2100?
Here, the resolution is determined by the conjunction of three actions performed by a single human:
They voluntarily underwent a hemispherectomy.
Half of their brain was placed in long-term cryopreservation while they were still legally alive.
They reported in a credible source (such as a media outlet or a forum with strong evidence of credibility) that the procedure was primarily for life extension purposes.

P.title: By 2030, will at least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For purposes of this question, deaths due to bioweapons, electricity grid failures, etc. don't count. Roughly, we are interested in "deaths due to kinetic attacks." The 9/11 attacks count because ramming planes into buildings to make them collapse is kinetic. Were someone to hack into the FDA and mess things up so as to delay vaccine approval, thereby causing tens of thousands of deaths, that would not count.
The attackers don't need to be the military of a nation-state; terrorist groups count and coalitions/alliances also count.
However, the attackers need to be "part of the same team" in some sense. Otherwise, this would resolve positive simply in virtue of the US annual homicide rate! If there were a series of race riots, insurrections, or acts of domestic terrorism linked together under one banner (e.g. white supremacy, antigovernment, or antipolice) that would count.
Yes, this means that (contrary to what the headline question would suggest) if the USA gets involved in several independent small-scale wars, the US casualties from which total more than 10,000 in a year, that would not count

para_P.title: By 2030, will a single conflict result in the deaths of at least 10,000 Americans in one year?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For this question, fatalities caused by bioweapons, power grid failures, etc., are excluded. We are specifically interested in "deaths due to kinetic attacks." The 9/11 attacks qualify because using planes to destroy buildings is kinetic. If someone were to hack into the FDA and disrupt vaccine approval, leading to tens of thousands of deaths, that would not qualify.
The perpetrators do not need to be a nation's military; terrorist organizations and coalitions/alliances are included.
However, the attackers must be "part of the same team" in some sense. Otherwise, this would resolve positively simply due to the US annual homicide rate! If there were a series of race riots, insurrections, or acts of domestic terrorism unified under one banner (e.g., white supremacy, anti-government, or anti-police), that would qualify.
Yes, this means that (contrary to what the headline question might suggest) if the USA engages in several independent small-scale wars, and the US casualties from these total more than 10,000 in a year, that would not qualify.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (Pakistan)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

para_P.title: In the event of at least one nuclear explosion by 2030, which nations will experience at least one casualty? (Pakistan)
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question is contingent upon at least one offensive nuclear explosion taking place between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. If no such explosion occurs anywhere on Earth during this period, all sub-questions below will be marked as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear explosion within this timeframe, the following sub-questions will be marked as Yes if there is at least one casualty from any nuclear explosion occurring in that country (or regions) at any point between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. If there are no such casualties, the sub-question will be marked as No. If the only nuclear explosions during this period occur outside of all the following areas (for example, in international waters or regions not listed below), all options below will be marked as No.
The casualty must be caused by the immediate effects of the explosion; casualties caused by fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not be considered for resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear explosion" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorized nuclear explosions by state or non-state actors, but does not include explosions for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such explosions cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test explosions and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as explosions that are claimed to be a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. The final determination of whether an explosion is a test/peaceful explosion is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

An explosion will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

P.title: Will Brazil win the FIFA World Cup by the end of 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
2050 World Cup is included to this resolution.
FIFA World Cup is considered the official tournament hosted under FIFA.
If any World Cup prior of 2050 is moved after 2050 it does not count

para_P.title: Is it possible for Brazil to secure a FIFA World Cup victory by the year 2050?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The 2050 World Cup is included in this resolution.
The FIFA World Cup is recognized as the official tournament organized by FIFA.
If any World Cup scheduled before 2050 is postponed to a date after 2050, it will not be considered.

P.title: Will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Climate change geoengineering, defined by the United Kingdom’s Royal Society as “the deliberate large-scale manipulation of the planetary environment to counteract anthropogenic climate change” (Shepherd et al. 2009). Geoengineering involves the removal of greenhouse gases from the atmosphere, or attempts at reflecting more energy away from the planet to counter warming (Markusson et al., 2013). Geoengineering is often presented as a complement, and sometimes alternative, to climate mitigation and adaptation.
There are serious and complex governance issues which need to be resolved if geoengineering is ever to become an acceptable method for moderating climate change. It would be highly undesirable for irreversible global geoengineering to occur before appropriate governance mechanisms are in place. The Royal Society has published a set of geoengineering governance principles, known as The Oxford Principles, which aims to guide the collaborative development of geoengineering governance, from the earliest stages of research, to any eventual deployment. These principles are:
Principle 1: Geoengineering is to be regulated as a public good
Principle 2: The public should participate in geoengineering decision-making
Principle 3: Geoengineering research and results should be publicly disclosed
Principle 4: There should be independent assessments of the impacts
Principle 5: governance systems should be developed before geoengineering methods are deployed
As of September 2019, two geoengineering bills and one resolution have been introduced in Congress. These bills are the following:
Geoengineering Research Evaluation Act of 2017. This bill recommends a research agenda for advancing understanding of albedo modification strategies that involve atmospheric interventions, such as cloud modification; and a report that provides specific guidance on the governance mechanisms for the proposed research agenda.
American Clean Energy Leadership Act of 2009. This bill requires the Secretary of Energy to establish an Advisory Committee on Geosciences and Geoengineering Education to advise the Secretary in education and training in the subsurface geosciences and engineering.
Neither the Geoengineering Research Evaluation Act of 2017 nor the American Clean Energy Leadership Act of 2009 became legislation. So far, the U.S. has not enacted legislation that are explicitly related to geoengineering.
Will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024?
This questions resolves positively if a geoengineering bill that is introduced in the House of Representatives and/or the Senate is subsequently enacted as legislation (by being signed by the U.S. president, or through other means) before or on 31/12/2024. For the purpose of this question, a geoengineering bill is any bill reported by the relevant Congress website search. This search involves the following terms:
"Climate engineering" OR "geoengineering" OR "Solar radiation management" OR "Stratospheric Particle Injection" OR "Stratospheric aerosol injection" OR "Marine cloud brightening" OR "Ocean sulfur cycle enhancement"

para_P.title: Will a geoengineering bill be enacted into US federal law by the end of 2024?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Climate change geoengineering, as defined by the United Kingdom’s Royal Society, refers to “the deliberate large-scale manipulation of the planetary environment to counteract anthropogenic climate change” (Shepherd et al. 2009). This includes the removal of greenhouse gases from the atmosphere or efforts to reflect more solar energy away from Earth to mitigate warming (Markusson et al., 2013). Geoengineering is often seen as a supplement, and occasionally an alternative, to climate mitigation and adaptation.
There are significant and intricate governance issues that must be addressed for geoengineering to be considered a viable method for addressing climate change. It is crucial to avoid irreversible global geoengineering actions before establishing proper governance frameworks. The Royal Society has outlined a set of geoengineering governance principles, known as The Oxford Principles, to guide the collaborative development of geoengineering governance from the initial research stages to any potential deployment. These principles are:
Principle 1: Geoengineering should be regulated as a public good
Principle 2: Public participation in geoengineering decision-making is essential
Principle 3: Geoengineering research and findings should be publicly accessible
Principle 4: Independent evaluations of the impacts are necessary
Principle 5: Governance systems should be in place before deploying geoengineering methods
As of September 2019, Congress has introduced two geoengineering bills and one resolution. These bills are:
Geoengineering Research Evaluation Act of 2017. This bill proposes a research agenda to advance the understanding of albedo modification strategies involving atmospheric interventions, such as cloud modification, and a report providing specific guidance on governance mechanisms for the proposed research agenda.
American Clean Energy Leadership Act of 2009. This bill mandates the Secretary of Energy to establish an Advisory Committee on Geosciences and Geoengineering Education to advise on education and training in subsurface geosciences and engineering.
Neither the Geoengineering Research Evaluation Act of 2017 nor the American Clean Energy Leadership Act of 2009 became law. To date, the U.S. has not enacted legislation explicitly related to geoengineering.
Will a geoengineering bill be enacted into US federal law by the end of 2024?
This question will be resolved positively if a geoengineering bill introduced in the House of Representatives and/or the Senate is enacted as legislation (either by being signed by the U.S. president or through other means) on or before 31/12/2024. For this question, a geoengineering bill is defined as any bill identified by the relevant Congress website search using the following terms:
"Climate engineering" OR "geoengineering" OR "Solar radiation management" OR "Stratospheric Particle Injection" OR "Stratospheric aerosol injection" OR "Marine cloud brightening" OR "Ocean sulfur cycle enhancement"

P.title: Will mixed doubles be a fixture at all four slams in 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve according to whether or not all four slam events hold a mixed doubles competition with elite players. we define a mixed doubles competition to be an elite competition if it includes:
at least 4 teams with men in the top 100 (singles or doubles ranking)
at least 4 teams with women in the top 100 (singles or doubles ranking)
at least 10 teams in total (ie more than straight quarterfinals, but byes in the first round are acceptable)
If the list of tournaments which are considered a slam changes, we will limit the list to the four which most resemble the historic 4.
In the event no slams take place in 2040, we will resolve based the nearest year with earlier taking preference, ie 2039, 2041, 2038, 2042, et

para_P.title: Will mixed doubles be a regular event at all four Grand Slam tournaments in 2040?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be settled based on whether all four Grand Slam tournaments feature a mixed doubles event with top-tier players. A mixed doubles event is considered top-tier if it includes:
- at least 4 teams with men ranked in the top 100 (singles or doubles ranking)
- at least 4 teams with women ranked in the top 100 (singles or doubles ranking)
- at least 10 teams in total (i.e., more than just quarterfinals, but byes in the first round are acceptable)
If the list of tournaments classified as Grand Slams changes, we will restrict the list to the four that most closely resemble the traditional four.
If no Grand Slam tournaments occur in 2040, we will resolve based on the nearest year, with earlier years taking precedence, e.g., 2039, 2041, 2038, 2042, etc.

P.title: Will the IAU rework its definition of planetary status by Jan 1, 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The International Astronomical Union defines a planet [1] as a celestial body that
is in orbit around the Sun,
is massive enough per material strength to be an ellipsoid (in hydrostatic equilibrium) and,
has "cleared the neighborhood" around its orbit.
A debate has emerged in the planetary sciences over whether the community should instead embrace a purely geophysical definition of a planet (a substellar body in hydrostatic equilibrium), stated in more detail here: [2]. This point of view has been gaining some traction, e.g. in Metzger et al. 2018 [3].
The chief concerns with the IAU's definition are that it excludes exoplanets (they do not orbit the sun), small bodies in hydrostatic equilibrium (e.g. Pluto, Ceres, Titan, Quaoar), and that "clearing the neighborhood" is an imprecise definition that has many caveats (e.g. coorbital bodies/quasi-satellites). There have been attempts to rigorously define orbital clearing (e.g. Margot 2015 [4]), but they have not yet been adopted by the IAU.
The chief concerns with the geophysical definition are that it elides dynamical concerns (which are integral to planet formation), includes ellipsoidal satellites (e.g. Titan, Triton, Ganymede) as planets, and will result in having >50 planets, with that number growing as time goes on.
This debate conceals a difference in methodological approach - considering whether small, ellipsoidal (currently) subplanetary bodies* are more interesting in particular (as geophysical entities, like Earth) or in aggregate (as orbital populations, like sub-ellipsoidal asteroids). These concerns are, to first order, native to planetary geoscientists and planetary astronomers/dynamicists respectively. The geophysical and IAU definitions are both used in the literature, again employed ~along subdisciplinary lines.
This now brings us to the question: given the ongoing debate and reality of publishing differences the planetary sciences,
will the IAU revise its definition of a planet before 2025?
Resolution details
IAU's 2006 definition is:
A “planet” is defined as a celestial body that (a) is in orbit around the Sun, (b) has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium (nearly round) shape, and (c) has cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit.
We'll refer to this as the "original definition". This question resolves positively if any of the following occurs:
Any of the Parts (a), (b) or (c) of the original definition are substantially revised; or
Any of the Parts (a), (b) or (c) of the original definition are removed; or
Another part not included in the original definition is included that requires a planet to have an additional property that is not implicit in parts (a), (b) or (c).
If more than one of these conditions occur, the question also resolves positively.
[1] IAU Definition
[2] Geophysical Definition
[3] Metzger et al. 2018
[4] Margot 2015
*currently characterized by the IAU as "dwarf planets"

para_P.title: Will the IAU amend its criteria for planetary classification by January 1, 2025?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The International Astronomical Union (IAU) currently defines a planet [1] as a celestial body that
orbits the Sun,
has enough mass for its self-gravity to form a nearly round shape (hydrostatic equilibrium), and,
has "cleared the neighborhood" around its orbit.
A debate has arisen in the planetary science community about whether a purely geophysical definition of a planet (a substellar body in hydrostatic equilibrium) should be adopted instead, as detailed here: [2]. This perspective has been gaining support, for example, in Metzger et al. 2018 [3].
The main issues with the IAU's definition are that it excludes exoplanets (which do not orbit the Sun), small bodies in hydrostatic equilibrium (e.g., Pluto, Ceres, Titan, Quaoar), and that "clearing the neighborhood" is a vague criterion with many exceptions (e.g., coorbital bodies/quasi-satellites). Attempts have been made to define orbital clearing more precisely (e.g., Margot 2015 [4]), but these have not been adopted by the IAU.
The main issues with the geophysical definition are that it ignores dynamical aspects (which are crucial to planet formation), includes ellipsoidal satellites (e.g., Titan, Triton, Ganymede) as planets, and would result in more than 50 planets, with that number increasing over time.
This debate reflects a methodological divide—whether small, ellipsoidal (currently) subplanetary bodies* are more interesting individually (as geophysical entities, like Earth) or collectively (as orbital populations, like sub-ellipsoidal asteroids). These concerns are primarily of interest to planetary geoscientists and planetary astronomers/dynamicists, respectively. Both the geophysical and IAU definitions are used in the literature, often along subdisciplinary lines.
This leads us to the question: given the ongoing debate and the differences in publishing within planetary sciences,
will the IAU change its definition of a planet before 2025?
Resolution details
The IAU's 2006 definition is:
A “planet” is defined as a celestial body that (a) orbits the Sun, (b) has enough mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces and form a nearly round shape (hydrostatic equilibrium), and (c) has cleared the neighborhood around its orbit.
We'll refer to this as the "original definition." This question resolves positively if any of the following occurs:
Any of the Parts (a), (b), or (c) of the original definition are substantially revised; or
Any of the Parts (a), (b), or (c) of the original definition are removed; or
Another part not included in the original definition is added that requires a planet to have an additional property not implicit in parts (a), (b), or (c).
If more than one of these conditions occur, the question also resolves positively.
[1] IAU Definition
[2] Geophysical Definition
[3] Metzger et al. 2018
[4] Margot 2015
*currently classified by the IAU as "dwarf planets"

P.title: Will the next assassination of a sitting US President occur after January 1, 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if every US President serving from January 20, 2017 to January 1, 2100 serves their term without successfully being assassinated.
Any assassination attempt which does not lead directly to a US President's medical death will not trigger resolution. Any assassination of a US President who is not currently holding that office will also not trigger resolution. Attacks which target a broad group of people (such as nuclear or biological weapons) may qualify as an "assassination" if it can be determined that the attacker intended to target the President (whether or not other individuals were also a target)

para_P.title: Will any sitting US President be assassinated after January 1, 2100?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if every US President serving from January 20, 2017 to January 1, 2100 completes their term without being successfully assassinated.
Any assassination attempt that does not result in the immediate medical death of a US President will not cause resolution. Any assassination of a US President who is not in office at the time will also not cause resolution. Attacks aimed at a large group of people (such as those involving nuclear or biological weapons) may be considered an "assassination" if it is clear that the attacker intended to target the President (regardless of whether other individuals were also targeted).

P.title: Will Iran possess a nuclear weapon before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the Iranian Government credibly states that it has a nuclear weapon or has tested a nuclear weapon at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, according to credible media reports.
Fine Print
For these purposes we do not consider a radiological weapon — where any fission/fusion energy is energetically sub-dominant to chemical or other explosives — to constitute a nuclear detonation.
For the purpose of this question, no missiles are required to carry the nuclear weapons (e.g. a nuclear warhead alone is sufficient for positive resolution).
The deliberate detonation of nuclear weapons primarily for non-offensive engineering, mining or other civilian purposes (on Earth or in Space) will be sufficient to resolve this question as Yes.
Purchase of or gift of nuclear weapon to Iran will resolve this question as Yes.

para_P.title: Will Iran have a nuclear weapon by 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be answered affirmatively if the Iranian Government credibly announces that it possesses a nuclear weapon or has conducted a nuclear test at any point from January 1, 2020, to January 1, 2030, as reported by credible media sources.
Fine Print
For the purposes of this question, a radiological weapon — where the energy from fission/fusion is less significant than that from chemical or other explosives — will not be considered a nuclear detonation.
No missile delivery system is required for the nuclear weapon (e.g., a nuclear warhead alone is sufficient for a positive resolution).
The intentional detonation of nuclear weapons mainly for non-offensive engineering, mining, or other civilian purposes (on Earth or in Space) will be enough to answer this question affirmatively.
The acquisition or gifting of a nuclear weapon to Iran will also result in a Yes resolution.

P.title: Before 1 January 2050, will any human cryonically preserved for at least 1 year be successfully revived?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
As of 2014, around 250 legally dead people in the United States were in cryonic preservation. At least 1,500 people around the world have active plans to join them in cryopreservation in an attempt to thwart (or at least delay) permanent death by freezing (or more technically 'vitrifying') their corpses after their legal death. Many of these 'cryopatients' have had their whole bodies preserved; others have opted to have only a cheaper neuropreservation. You can probably guess what that means. For more information on the current state of the art in cryonics, you can visit Alcor's website, which is one of the most prominent organisations in the field.
This question asks: will any 'patients' who have been in cryonic preservation for at least one full year before 2050 be successfully revived before 1 January 2050?
For the purposes of this question, a revived patient must be determined by at least three recognized medical experts (M.D. or PhD in Biology, Neuroscience or equivalent level of education), each of whom is independent of the cryonics organisation responsible for the patient, to be conscious, alert and responsive to questions for at least 24 hours at some point within a year and a day after midnight on the date that the attempt to revive them is made.

para_P.title: By January 1, 2050, will any human who has been cryonically preserved for a minimum of one year be successfully brought back to life?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
As of 2014, approximately 250 legally deceased individuals in the United States were undergoing cryonic preservation. Globally, at least 1,500 people have plans to undergo cryopreservation in an effort to prevent (or at least postpone) permanent death by freezing (or more precisely 'vitrifying') their bodies after legal death. Many of these 'cryopatients' have chosen whole-body preservation, while others have opted for the more affordable neuropreservation. You can probably infer what that entails. For more details on the current advancements in cryonics, you can visit the website of Alcor, one of the leading organizations in this field.
This question inquires: will any 'patients' who have been cryonically preserved for at least one full year before 2050 be successfully revived before January 1, 2050?
For the purpose of this question, a revived patient must be confirmed by at least three recognized medical experts (M.D. or PhD in Biology, Neuroscience, or an equivalent level of education), each of whom is independent of the cryonics organization responsible for the patient, to be conscious, alert, and responsive to questions for at least 24 hours at some point within a year and a day after midnight on the date the revival attempt is made.

P.title: Will Europa be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extra terrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.
Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.

para_P.title: Will humanity first discover extraterrestrial life on Europa before 2045?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be answered with Yes if humanity finds convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045, and this discovery occurs before detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is convincingly found elsewhere before being found on Europa, this question will be answered with No. If no extraterrestrial life is discovered before 2045, this question will be Annulled.
Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) currently living and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.

P.title: Will 3 mainstream American news outlets report that a rebel group perpetrated the 2013 Ghouta Chemical Attack before August 21, 2033?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, on or before August 21, 2033 (20 years after the Ghouta chemical attack), three major mainstream American news outlets run an article suggesting that the Syrian government may not have carried out the Ghouta chemical attack, and at least one author of each of the articles believes that there is a more than 50% probability that the Syrian government did not carry out the attack. Otherwise this question will resolve as No.
Fine Print
A year is given to make sure we know the author's opinions. The article cannot be an op-ed; it has to be reporting. A "major mainstream news outlet" refers to one of the following:
ABC News
CBS News
CNN
MSNBC
NBC News
The New York Times
The Washington Post
Bloomberg
NPR
The New Yorker

para_P.title: Will three prominent American news organizations report that a rebel faction was responsible for the 2013 Ghouta Chemical Attack before August 21, 2033?

Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, on or before August 21, 2033 (20 years after the Ghouta chemical attack), three major mainstream American news organizations publish an article indicating that the Syrian government might not have been responsible for the Ghouta chemical attack, and at least one author of each article believes there is a greater than 50% chance that the Syrian government was not responsible for the attack. Otherwise, this question will resolve as No.
Fine Print
A year is given to ensure we understand the author's opinions. The article cannot be an op-ed; it must be a news report. A "major mainstream news organization" refers to one of the following:

P.title: Will Apollo 10's Lunar Module be recovered by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Lunar Module flown on Apollo 10 is the only flown lunar module which didn't end up crashing into the Moon or burning up in Earth's atmosphere.
After 'dress rehearsal' testing in lunar orbit, during which the Lunar Module came within 8.4 nautical miles of the lunar surface, the ascent engine performed a burn to depletion which sent the craft into interplanetary space and the vehicle is currently in a heliocentric orbit. The location of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is unknown as of May 2019, but efforts are underway to find it.
As a unique historical artefact from the original golden age of human spaceflight, this Lunar Module would certainly make for an interesting museum exhibit.
This question asks: by 1 January 2050, will the lost ascent stage of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module be recovered (i.e. located, captured, and physically transported to some location where humans have a presence at that time, such as Earth, the Moon, Mars or elsewhere) successfully?

para_P.title: Will the Apollo 10 Lunar Module be retrieved by the year 2050?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Lunar Module used in the Apollo 10 mission is the only one that neither crashed into the Moon nor burned up in Earth's atmosphere.
After conducting 'dress rehearsal' tests in lunar orbit, during which the Lunar Module approached within 8.4 nautical miles of the lunar surface, the ascent engine executed a burn to depletion, sending the craft into interplanetary space. It is currently in a heliocentric orbit, and its location has been unknown since May 2019, although efforts to locate it are ongoing.
As a unique historical artifact from the original golden age of human space exploration, this Lunar Module would make a fascinating museum exhibit.
This question asks: by January 1, 2050, will the lost ascent stage of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module be successfully recovered (i.e., found, captured, and physically transported to a location where humans are present at that time, such as Earth, the Moon, Mars, or another location)?

P.title: Will there be any progress in human lifespan enhancement by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occur before January 1, 2100:
At least 10 people have confirmed lifespans of at least 130 years of age
At least 100 people have confirmed lifespans of at least 120 years of age
Ray Kurzweil lives to the age of 120
The verification process on these individuals' lifespans should be at least as strict as the standards used during 2018. People resuscitated after being cryonically frozen will not be included in this question's resolution

P.title: Will Iran recognize Israel before 2070?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the State of Israel is formally recognized by the government of Iran at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2070.
Fine Print
The recognition can be done by the Islamic Republic of Iran or by any state that has de facto control of more than 50% (by area) of the land currently controlled by the Islamic Republic of Iran.

para_P.title: Will Iran acknowledge Israel's statehood before 2070?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the State of Israel is officially acknowledged by the government of Iran at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2070.
Fine Print
The acknowledgment can be done by the Islamic Republic of Iran or by any state that has de facto control of more than 50% (by area) of the land currently governed by the Islamic Republic of Iran.

P.title: By 2100, will the human population decrease by at least 10% during any period of 5 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the human population (on Earth, and possibly elsewhere) decreases by at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.
This question is part of the Ragnarök Question Series. Check out the other questions in the series:
If a global biological catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If an artificial intelligence catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If a nuclear catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If a global climate disaster occurs by 2100, will the human population decline by 95% or more?
If a global nanotechnology catastrophe occurs by 2100, will the human population decline by 95% or more?
Also, please check out our questions on whether a global catastrophe will occur by 2100, and if so, which?:

Will such a catastrophe be due to a nanotechnology failure-mode?

All results are analysed here, and will be updated periodically.

P.title: Does P = NP?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If no award is given by the Clay Institute (between January 1, 2000 to January 1, 2100) for a proof or disproof of P = NP, this question will resolve ambiguously. The question will resolve ambiguously also if the problem is proven to not have a solution either way, e.g. if the problem will turn out to be unprovable or undecidable. If resolution is positive, the close date will be set retroactively to the date of complete initial publication (in journal or preprint form) of the proof, plus one year (or one day before the date of announcement of the prize, if that comes earlier.)
As some background, Gerhard J. Woeginger maintains a list of claimed proofs of the problem. As of 2018, the list contains 62 purported proofs of P = NP, 50 of P ≠ NP, 2 proofs the problem is unprovable, and one proof that it is undecidable. William I. Gasarch asked 100 various theorists the question whether P = NP. The result are as follows:
61 thought P≠NP.
9 thought P=NP.
4 thought that it is independent.
3 just stated that it is NOT independent of Primitive Recursive Arithmetic.
1 said it would depend on the model.
22 offered no opinion

para_P.title: Is P equal to NP?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If the Clay Institute does not award a prize (between January 1, 2000 to January 1, 2100) for proving or disproving P = NP, this question will be considered unresolved. The question will also be unresolved if it is shown that the problem cannot be solved either way, such as if it is unprovable or undecidable. If resolved positively, the close date will be set retroactively to the date of the initial complete publication (in journal or preprint form) of the proof, plus one year (or one day before the prize announcement, if that occurs earlier.)
For context, Gerhard J. Woeginger keeps a list of claimed proofs of the problem. As of 2018, the list includes 62 claimed proofs of P = NP, 50 of P ≠ NP, 2 proofs that the problem is unprovable, and one proof that it is undecidable. William I. Gasarch surveyed 100 theorists on whether P = NP. The results were:
61 believed P≠NP.
9 believed P=NP.
4 believed it is independent.
3 stated it is NOT independent of Primitive Recursive Arithmetic.
1 said it depends on the model.
22 had no opinion

P.title: Will MIRI employ researchers in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, on 2030-01-01 MIRI exists and employs researchers to work on AI Safety.
For the purpose of this question AI Safety is broadly defined as any technical work, at any level of abstraction, focused on the alignment of AI systems, existing or hypothetical, with some broad notion of human interests.
Research is here defined as involving developing novel ideas and insights broadly in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields (such as computer science or mathematics) at the time. Currently, blog posts alone wouldn't count for resolution as this does not currently conform to the standard format of academic publications. For the purpose of this question, such research need not be published nor made publicly available. In case it is unclear whether this work is done, a moderator may contact MIRI to confirm.
If MIRI changes its name, the new organization is used for resolution as if there was no name change. If MIRI merges into another organization, the resulting merged organization is used for resolution. In case of a dispute over the question resolution criteria, if at least one moderator and admin concur that the resolution criteria must change, then it shall. In case of a dispute between admins, a vote in the comment section will determine the correct resolution.
In case MIRI's research is circulated internally only, the requirement that the work need to be "developed in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields" will not apply.

para_P.title: Will MIRI have researchers on staff in 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves affirmatively if, on 2030-01-01, MIRI is operational and employs researchers dedicated to AI Safety.
For the purpose of this question, AI Safety is broadly defined as any technical work, at any level of abstraction, focused on aligning AI systems, whether existing or hypothetical, with broad human interests.
Research is defined here as the development of novel ideas and insights, generally in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields (such as computer science or mathematics) at the time. Currently, blog posts alone would not qualify for resolution as they do not conform to the standard format of academic publications. For the purpose of this question, such research need not be published or made publicly available. If it is unclear whether this work is being done, a moderator may contact MIRI for confirmation.
If MIRI changes its name, the new organization will be used for resolution as if there was no name change. If MIRI merges with another organization, the resulting merged entity will be used for resolution. In case of a dispute over the question resolution criteria, if at least one moderator and admin agree that the resolution criteria must change, then it shall. In case of a dispute among admins, a vote in the comment section will determine the correct resolution.
If MIRI's research is circulated internally only, the requirement that the work be "developed in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields" will not apply.
